title: Make It Shine! Arduino Kit
description: Our one-of-a-kind method of introducing microcontroller programming enables even novice students to design and build sophisticated electronic inventions. The hardware in this kit is hand-selected to minimize student frustration and increase self-sufficiency. Programming concepts are introduced through a block-based, graphical language. Later, students who are ready can move on to native Arduino code. Programming can be done from an iPad, laptop, or Chromebook.Students will use found materials such as boxes, felt, or straws to build a sculpture or model that uses digitally controlled light as a component. Students will also program a microcontroller to  control the sequence of lights and their brightness. This is a great kit for anyone just getting started with microcontroller programming.Students will learn circuits, digital logic, LED properties, beginner programming (loops, variables).When students have mastered the basics, this kit can be supplimented wiht the sensor add-on pack or the servo add-on pack to bring even more interactivity to a student sculpture.Includes a detailed student project guide.
specifications: Kit Contains:10 Red LEDs10 Green LEDs10 Yellow LEDs2 Cell Battery HolderArduino MicrocontrollerBreadboard (small clear)Jumper Wires (30 Pack)Copper TapeStudent Manual
short_description: Empower student innovation by introducing them to how to program a microcontroller. Students will incorporate digitally controlled light into a sculpture made from found and repurposed materials.The materials in this kit are specifically selected to make concepts easy to learn for beginners.

title: Make It Go! Arduino Kit
description: Our one-of-a-kind method of introducing microcontroller programming enables even novice students to design and build sophisticated electronic inventions. The hardware in this kit is hand-selected to minimize student frustration and increase self-sufficiency. Programming concepts are introduced through a block-based, graphical language. Later, students who are ready can move on to native Arduino code. Programming can be done from an iPad, laptop, or Chromebook.This kit contains everything a student needs to control two DC motors. Students learn how to program a microcontroller to turn two motors in both directions. Students will connect a motor driver to a microcontroller and see how their lines of code can change the speed or direction of motors. Once they have mastered the basics of motor controll, they are ready to put their creativity and problem-solving skills to work by designing the chassis and wheel system for a vehicle. Students will experiment to find what types of wheel designs work best on different surfaces and how the overall design of the vehicle affects its speed, manuverability, serviceability (changing batteries) and durability. Select between a version that allows students to learn how to solder some simple components or a version where all parts are pre-soldered.Detailed student project guide is included.
specifications: Kit contains:10 Red LEDs10 Green LEDs10 Yellow LEDs4 Cell Battery HolderArduino Compatible MicrocontrollerMotor DriverPair of DC MotorsPair of WheelsBreadboard (small clear)Jumper Wires (30 Pack)Student Manual
short_description: Student will have to get creative as they design and build a robotic vehicle controlled by an Arduino. Students create a program that controls two DC motors to drive in any direction.

title: Make It Move! Arduino Kit
description: Standard DC motors are great for driving vehicle wheels. In order to capture more precise movements, however, students must learn how to control a servo motor. Students can build increasingly complex inventions by connecting varous found materials such as levers, gears, and pulleys. Our one-of-a-kind method of introducing microcontroller programming enables even novice students to design and build sophisticated electronic inventions. The hardware in this kit is hand-selected to minimize student frustration and increase self-sufficiency. Programming concepts are introduced through a block-based, graphical language. Later, students who are ready can move on to native Arduino code. Programming can be done from an iPad, laptop, or Chromebook.Includes detailed student project guide.
specifications: Kit Includes10 Red LEDs10 Green LEDs10 Yellow LEDs2 Cell Battery HolderArduino Microcontroller2x Micro Servo MotorsBreadboard (small clear)Jumper Wires (30 Pack)Student Manual
short_description: Monsters with arms that move, robotic hands that grip, automated laser pointers are all possible inventions when your students learn how to control a servo motor with an Arduino microcontroller. Students learn how to innovate as they use found and repurposed materials to design and build things that move.

title: Robot Activity Mat
description: This mat gives studetns an ideal surface to execute robotic activity. It is available in sizes of 4' x 4', 6' x 6' or 8' x 8'. It is imprinted with either a cartesian coordinate grid or with polar coordinates. Students can use eraseable markers to design a variety of challenges and games.
short_description: Students can use eraseable markers to draw challenges or to design competitive games. A precise grid marked out in centimeters give students the opportunity to measure precise distances traveled when testing robot movements.

title: Makerspace in a Box -- Materials
description: No time to visit the craft store or local hardware shop? We can help with our Makerspace in a Box! Our teachers have compiled a list of materials that kids use regularly and successfully and packaged them in this kit to help you get off to a strong start. This kit will help you learn what types of materials and supplies work best in your environment with your students.
specifications: Aluminum Foil Play DohTempora Paints & BrushesBrass FastnersThumb TacksRubber Bands (Large bag)Glitter Glue PensDuct Tape (4 rolls)ClothespinsCreatology Craft Value PackCreatology Asorted Wood ShapesWood skill sticksSmall wood spools (6) - great as pulleysConstruction paper (200 Sheets)Model Magic 1 tubWashable Markers 4 Packs of 50Foam Core board 10 piecesConductive Paint
short_description: Most schools will stock their makerspaces as they learn what materials and tools work best for them. This kit will help you get started with an inital stock of materials and supplies that have proven themselves useful in school makerspaces.

title: Makerspace in a Box -- Tools
description: As your makerspace grows you will learn what tools work best and customize your space on your own. This kit will get you started with the basics, so you can hit the ground running in your new makerspace.This kit comes with suggested safety policies for classroom use of tools and a student guide for proper tool use.
specifications: Kit ContainsNeedle nose pliers (4)Diagonal Cutters (2)Wire strippers (5)Hot Glue Guns w. Glue Sticks (4)Make Do Cardboard Construction Kits (4)Safety Goggles (5)Coping Saw (1)Miter Saw w. Box (1)hand saw (1)Rotary Tool (1)Power Drill (1)Bit Set (1)Staple Gun (1)Hammers (3)Nails (1 box)Screwdriver set (1)Precision Screwdrivers (4)Box cutters (6)Measuring tape (1)xactocutting matsoldering iron (3)helping hands (3)multi meter (10)
short_description: You don't need to invest in expensive digital fabrication tools and 3D printers for your students to build things. This collection of simple tools will give students the resources they need to turn their imaginary creations into reality.

title: Makerspace in a Box -- Electronics
description: As your makerspace gets up and running, you will learn what components are most important to your students. This kit will give you a basic stock of parts that can be used in a wide array of electronics projects to get you started.
specifications: Kit Contains:22 Gauge Solid Core Copper Wire2 AA battery holder (15)10MM LEDs assorted colors (80)5mm LEDs assorted colors (60)Force Sensitive Resistor  (15)Jumper Wires (15 packs of 30)Piezo Element (15)Mini Photocell  (15)Makey Makey Boards  (15)Arduino Boards  (15)Sparkfun Motor Driver  (15)Tilt Sensor  (15)Servo - sub micro  (15)Trimpot  (15)Pair of Wheels  (15)Breadboard  (15)Hobby Gearmotor  (15)
short_description: This collection of electronics will help you stock your makerspace with the components that students will need for a wide variety of basic projects. Compiled with input from teachers and makerspace coordinators, these are the components that have proven to be most useful.

title: Online Course--Arduino Basics for Teachers
description: The course runs for two weeks. Participants should plan on spending approximately 4 hours per week on coursework.Each student will be shipped a kit containing the electronics and materials to complete three different projects.We will collaborate and share information each week using the Haiku learning management system. Participants will receive a course code allowing them to join the Haiku course. We will also host a "Project Showcase" at the end of the course through a live Google Hangout where participants will have the opportunity to show what they created and share what they learned.
short_description: Curious about programmable electronics, but you aren't quite sure how to get started? This online course will give you everything you need to master the basics.Includes all electronic materials you need to complete the projects and guided instruction.

title: Raspberry Pi Model 1 B
description: A Raspberry Pi is a fully functional Linux computer. Plug a monitor, keyboard and mouse into this tiny board and connect to an ethernet cable, and you can be searching the web, composing in Google Docs, or programming in scratch or Python in a few minutes. GPIO pins allow you to connect your own electronic inventions to the board and interact with the programs you write in Python. This is is a great intro to Linux, physical computing, and electronics. Suggested for students in grade 8 and above.
short_description: Give student tinkerers a chance to build and program their own Linux computer. Teach them how to connect it to the world around them through the GPIO pins and write software to read sensor data, drive motors, lights and other things.

title: Make it All: Arduino Kit
description: Our one-of-a-kind method of introducing microcontroller programming enables even novice students to design and build sophisticated electronic inventions. The hardware in this kit is hand-selected to minimize student frustration and increase self-sufficiency. Programming concepts are introduced through a block-based, graphical language. Later, students who are ready can move on to native Arduino code. Programming can be done from an iPad, laptop, or Chromebook.Students will learn how to control LEDs, servo motors, and DC motors with an Arduino as they progress through three engaging challenges. NOTE: Crafting supplies and found materials for creations are NOT included. Suggested for students grade 6 and up.
specifications: 10 Red LEDs10 Green LEDs10 Yellow LEDs4x AA Battery HolderArduino MicrocontrollerMotor DriverPair of DC MotorsPair of WheelsJumper Wires2 Micro Servo MotorsBreadboard (small clear)Jumper Wires (30 Pack)Student Manual
seo_description: This is the best method for introducing students to arduino and microcontrollers. Program from an iPad or laptop using block-based graphical language or native arduino code.
seo_keywords: Arduino car,arduino makerspace,makerspace,learn arduino,simple arduino kits,arduino for students,arduino for kids,arduino for schools,how to build a robot
short_description: Empower student innovation as they build three projects that culminate in a programmable, autonomous vehicle using found and improvised materials. Students use a simple, block-based, graphical programming language on an iPad or a laptop to control an Arduino creation.

title: Arduino Uno
description: The product description text should go here...
short_description: This is the classic Arduino microcontroller board. Programmable over USB from any Mac, PC, or even Chromebook, this microcontroller gives students the power to plug in and control their electronic inventions.

title: 10mm (gumdrop) LED 20 Pack (Red, Yellow, Blue Green
description: This collection of large LEDs is easy to work with for small hands. Ideal for lessons in squishy circuits or paper circuits.
short_description: Total of 60 LEDs of assorted colors Red, Green, and Blue

title: Battery Holder 2xAA with Cover and Switch
description: This 2xAA battery holder puts a nice finishing touch on your battery powered project. This holder features a removable, sliding cover, which is secured with a small phillips head screw. Another bonus is the ON/OFF switch which can be used to control power to your project.The leads are about 150mm, and the last 5mm of them are tinned.
seo_description: Battery holder for robotics and electronics projects
short_description: This device pairs really well with the LIght Blue Bean. Providing more current than the standard coin cell, it does not exceed the voltage limit of the bean. Powerful enough to drive DC motors and servos. The on-off switch is also convenient.

title: Breadboard - Clear Self-Adhesive
description: Ever wonder what goes on inside these things? Well this clear bread board might enlighten.Beyond the clear plastic, this is really just a regular, solderless breadboard. It has 2 power buses, 30 columns, and 10 rows - a total of 400 tie in points. All pins are spaced by a standard 0.1". The two sets of five rows are separated by about 0.3", perfect for straddling a DIP package over. The board accepts wire sizes in the range of 29-20AWG.This board also has a self-adhesive on the back. The boards also have interlocking parts, so you can hook as many together as you’d like.Dimensions: 3.29 x 2.15 x 0.33" (83.5 x 54.5 x 8.5mm)
short_description: We bundle these half-sized breadboards with all of our Arduino kits because students find it easy to incorporate them into their inventions while allowing them to quickly modify and troubleshoot their project.. Plus, they look really cool.

title: Jumper Wires Standard 7" M/M Pack of 30
description: This is a great assortment of jumper wires. With these, students won't have to worry about cutting and stripping wires as they prototype their inventions. Not as durable as premium jumper wires, but they get the job done and keep costs down.Dimensions: 7" long
short_description: When you are introducing electronic circuits to a class full of students, having pre-cut jumper wires with solid ends that easily plug into a breadboard makes everyone's life easier. Students don't need to deal with cutting and stripping wires as they quickly prototype and build and revise.

title: SparkFun Motor Driver - Dual TB6612FNG (1A)
description: The TB6612FNG motor driver can control up to two DC motors at a constant current of 1.2A (3.2A peak). Two input signals (IN1 and IN2) can be used to control the motor in one of four function modes - CW, CCW, short-brake, and stop. The two motor outputs (A and B) can be separately controlled, the speed of each motor is controlled via a PWM input signal with a frequency up to 100kHz. The STBY pin should be pulled high to take the motor out of standby mode.Logic supply voltage (VCC) can be in the range of 2.7-5.5VDC, while the motor supply (VM) is limited to a maximum voltage of 15VDC. The output current is rated up to 1.2A per channel (or up to 3.2A for a short, single pulse).Board comes with all components installed as shown. Decoupling capacitors are included on both supply lines. All pins of the TB6612FNG are broken out to two 0.1" pitch headers; the pins are arranged such that input pins are on one side and output pins are on the other.Features:Power supply voltage: VM=15V max, VCC=2.7-5.5VOutput current: Iout=1.2A(average) / 3.2A (peak)Standby control to save powerCW/CCW/short brake/stop motor control modesBuilt-in thermal shutdown circuit and low voltage detecting circuitAll pins of the TB6612FNG broken out to 0.1" spaced pinsFiltering capacitors on both supply linesDimensions: 0.8x0.8"
short_description: This driver exposes students to the details of how to control motors with a microcontroller, but it does so in a structured, easy-to-understand way. Our Make it Go kit helps guide them in the process.

title: Hobby Gearmotor - 65 RPM (Right Angle, Pair)
description: These inexpensive motors geared down to 65 RPM can easily be hot glued into an improvised vehicle chassis and controlled by an Arduino. Attaching two independent motors in a vehicle provides a wealth of challenges including how to turn precisely, go in reverse, and chart a collision-free path forward.
short_description: Part of the Make it Go kit, these motors give students an opportunity to learn how to build an autonomous or remote controlled vehicle.

title: Wheel - 65mm (Rubber Tire, Pair)
description: These are a pair of basic, 65mm wheels with black rubber tires. These wheels are the same ones designed to fit onto DAGUs right angle gear motors utilized in the Magician Chassis and RedBot Kit. With these wheels you will be able to get almost any beginners robot project moving.These wheels are sold in packs of two.
short_description: Designed to fit the hobby gearmotors, these wheels allow students to set their vehicular inventions in motion.

title: Servo - Generic (Sub-Micro Size)
description: Here is a simple, low-cost, high quality servo for all your mechatronic needs. This servo is very similar in size and specifications to the Hitec HS-55. This little guy is able to take in 6 volts and deliver 20.8 oz-in. of maximum torque at 0.10 sec/60°This small servo comes with a standard 3 pin power and control cable, and all hardware listed below.Note: This servo is rated for 180° rotation, but in actuality it only hits ~160°.Features:Voltage: 4.8-6.0 VoltsTorque: 16.6/20.8 oz-in. (4.8/6.0V)Speed: 0.15/0.10 sec/60° (4.8/6.0V)Rotation: ~160°Single Top Ball BearingNylon Gears3-Pole Ferrite MotorIncludes:1x Micro Size Servo1x Single Arm Micro Horn1x Double Arm Micro Horn1x Four Point Micro Horn1x Circle Micro Horn2x 2x8mm Phillips ScrewDimension:31.8 x 11.7 x 29mmWire Length: 160mmWeight: 9g
short_description: Part of the Make it Move Arduino kit, the servo motor enables students to build projects with precise moving parts.

title: Trimpot 10K with Knob
description: There are lots of trimpots out there. Some are very large, some so small they require a screwdriver. Here at SparkFun, we just needed a simple one that worked. This 10K trimmable potentiometer has a small knob built right in and it’s breadboard friendly to boot! Perfect for your next LCD contrast adjuster, opamp setting, or volume level. This model # is TSR-3386U within the datasheet.
short_description: Because it can be manipulated directly, a potentiometer is a great way to introduce students to how resistance can affect voltage. In our Make it React kit, we use this to introduce students to other variable resistors like photocells or flex sensors.

title: 5mm LEDs (20 Pack) - Red, Green, Blue, Yellow
description: Ideal for use with the Make it Shine kit, this is a pack of basic red, yellow, blue and green 5mm LEDs (5 of each) all conveniently packaged in a nice reusable ESD safe bag.Includes:5x - Basic Red5x - Basic Yellow5x - Basic Blue5x - Basic Green
short_description: This collection of LEDs give students the ability to add light to their creations. They learn how to turn lights on and off as well as get them to fade and flash.

title: Magnet Square - 0.25"
description: These are small rare earth magnets - 0.25" cubed. Composed of Neodymium/Iron/Boron (NdFeB), these magnets are curiously strong and make for a great way to attach tools to a metal workbench, hold small children to a fridge, and as a trigger for reed switches.Activates the reed switch at a distance of about 3cm.
short_description: Use these magnets with sensors that respond to magnetic fields like a reed switch or hall effect sensor.

title: Piezo Element
description: Piezo elements come in handy when you need to detect vibration or a knock. You can use these for tap or knock sensors pretty easily by reading the voltage on the output. They can also be used for a very small audio transducer such as a buzzer.
short_description: Use this sensor in combination with an Arduino to detect vibrations.

title: Mini Photocell
description: This is a very small light sensor. A photocell changes (also called a photodetector, photo resistor, CdS or photoconductive cell) resistance depending on the amount of light it is exposed to. These little sensors make great ambient light triggers (when light in the room turns on, do something).
short_description: Use with an Arduino to sense changes in light.

title: Force Sensitive Resistor
description: This is a force sensitive resistor with a round, 0.5" diameter, sensing area. This FSR will vary its resistance depending on how much pressure is being applied to the sensing area. The harder the force, the lower the resistance. When no pressure is being applied to the FSR its resistance will be larger than 1MΩ. This FSR can sense applied force anywhere in the range of 100g-10kg.Two pins extend from the bottom of the sensor with 0.1" pitch making it bread board friendly. There is a peel-and-stick rubber backing on the other side of the sensing area to mount the FSR.These sensors are simple to set up and great for sensing pressure, but they aren’t incredibly accurate. Use them to sense if it’s being squeezed, but you may not want to use it as a scale.
short_description: Connect to an Arduino to sense changes in pressure.

title: Tilt Sensor
description:
[ectext]

This AT407 basic tilt switch can easily be used to detect orientation. Inside the can is a ball that make contact with the pins when the case is upright. Tilt the case over and the balls don’t touch, thus not making a connection.

There are numerous uses for these basic sensors, but keep in mind you might need to use some debouncing code, as the sensor isn’t immune to small vibrations and such.

[/ectext]
short_description: Connect to an Arduino to detect tilts and changes in orientation.

title: Digital Multimeter
description:
[ectext]

The digital multimeter (DMM) is an essential tool in every electronic enthusiasts arsenal. The SparkFun Digital Multimeter, however, is not your average multimeter, it features a loud continuity sound, current/voltage sense, and quality probes. You can use the multimeter to measure DC and AC voltage, DC current, resistance, continuity, and test diodes. With this version we’ve done away with the bright flashy colors that can get us into trouble and gone with a nice, neutral gray. This multimeter should provoke no strong feelings one way or the other, we know this because our guts say “maybe.”

This isn’t your expensive, flashy type of multimeter, this is for all those starving students that need to buy their first good, low-cost digital multimeter. This meter doesn’t have the ability to auto-power off, it isn’t capable of auto-ranging, and it won’t be able to measure frequency. However, with this multimeter you WILL be able to measure DC Voltage from 200mV to 600V, AC Voltage from 200V and 600v, DC Current between 200uA to 10A, and Resistance from 0 to 20M Ohm. We even left a meter on to test the battery life - it lasted more than 170 hours (7 days) before the included 9V gave out!

[/ectext]
short_description: This inexpensive but indespensible tool for every electronics student can be used to measure voltage, resistance, and amperage.

title: 4x AA Battery Holder with Switch
description: This 4xAA battery holder puts a nice finishing touch on your battery powered project. This holder features a removable, sliding cover, which is secured with a small phillips head screw. Another bonus is the ON/OFF switch which can be used to control power to your project.The leads are about 150mm, and the last 5mm of them are tinned.
short_description: A good power supply for Squishy Circuits. Manual switch makes it easy to turn your invention on or off.

title: Makey Makey Standard Kit
description:
You may be the greatest living banana-pianist, but how will you ever know if you don’t make yourself a banana piano? Good news, that project and countless others are easier than you think they are with MaKey MaKey.

Using the MaKey MaKey you can make anything into a key (get it?) just by connecting a few alligator clips. The MaKey MaKey is an invention kit that tricks your computer into thinking that almost anything is a keyboard. This allows you to hook up all kinds of fun things as an input. For example, play Mario with a Play-Doh keyboard, or piano with fruit!
short_description: This is a great introduction to student invention and design. Using only alligator clips and household items (like a banana), students can engage in design-thinking activities and explore the properties of electronic circuits.

title: Copper Tape 5mm 50ft
description: Copper tape has countless applications in electronics from creating low-profile traces for electrical components to RF-shielding and antenna-making. Copper tape is even used to join things together using solder, like the stained glass on Tiffany lamps.This copper tape is adhesive-backed, 5mm wide and comes in rolls of 50 feet.
short_description: A key component of the paper circuits kit, this tape helps studetns to easily design circuits.

title: Sensor Essentials Kit
description:
[ectext]

Want to start playing with sensors, but don’t know where to begin? This kit includes a variety of basic sensors for any beginner or experienced programmer. With everything included in this kit, you’ll be able to sense acceleration, force, vibration, Infrared light, ambient light, temperature, and more! These are some great basic sensors from varying categories.

This huge assortment of sensors makes an amazing gift for that very special electronics geek; they won’t be able to thank you enough!

Kit Includes:

  • Triple Axis Accelerometer Breakout - Senses acceleration along all three axes, with a range of up to ±3g. Fully analog interface.
  • Hall Effect Sensor - Holding a magnet near this sensor will cause the output pin to toggle. This makes for a robust presence sensor.
  • Tilt Sensor - A simple AT407 basic tilt switch that can easily be used to detect orientation on your project.
  • Piezo Element - These two Piezo elements come in handy when you need to detect vibration or a knock. You can use these for tap or knock sensors pretty easily by reading the voltage on the output.
  • Insulated Reed Switch - Senses magnetic fields, makes for a great non-contact switch.
  • IR Receiver Diode - This is a miniaturized receiver for infrared remote control systems.
  • Infrared LED - This is a very simple, clear infrared LED. These devices operate between 940-950nm and work well for generic IR systems.
  • TMP36 - Temperature Sensor - The TMP36 is a low voltage, precision centigrade temperature sensor. It provides a voltage output that is linearly proportional to the Celsius temperature.
  • Trimpot 10K with Knob - This 10K trimmable potentiometer has a small knob built right in and it’s breadboard friendly to boot!
  • 0.25" Magnet Square - Plays nicely with the reed switch. Embed the magnet into stuffed animals or inside a box to create a hidden actuator to the reed switch.
  • 0.5" Force Sensitive Resistor - A force sensing resistor with a 0.5" diameter sensing area. Great for sensing pressure (i.e. if it’s being squeezed).
  • Mini Photocell - The photocell will vary its resistance based on how much light it’s exposed to. Will vary from 1kΩ in the light to 10kΩ in the dark.
  • Flex Sensor - As the sensor is flexed, the resistance across the sensor increases. Useful for sensing motion or positioning
  • Piezo Buzzer/Speaker - This is a small 12mm round speaker that operates around the audible 2kHz range. You can use these speakers to create simple music or user interfaces.
  • Resistor 1.0M Ohm 1/6 Watt PTH - Two 1/6th Watt, +/- 5% tolerance PTH resistors. Commonly used in breadboards and perf boards
    • [/ectext]
short_description: This is a great collection of various types of simple sensors to be used to introduce student to Arduino or Raspberry Pi input. Students learn about voltage and variable resistance to detect temperature, motion, and proximity.

title: Bare Conductive Classroom Pack
description:
[ectext]

This classroom pack from Bare Conductive provides you with everything you need to teach and engage up to 30 participants of any age the basics of circuits and electricity through the use of electrically conductive paint and crafts. This pack contains everything you need to lead a group ofstudents or friends through an activity to create a simple circuit using Electric Paint. Participants will be introduced to circuit symbols, component polarity and have the opportunity to attach a LED and coin cell battery to bring their own blinking robot greeting card to life!

Bare Conductive’s Electric Paint is just like any other water-based paint… except that it’s electrically conductive! This means that you can actually paint wires onto things like models, clothes, furniture, walls, almost anything you can think of and in this case, greeting cards. Standard acrylic or water-based paints can even be used alongside Electric Paint to act as insulation or to create multi-layer circuitry.

Note: Electric Paint is not meant for use on skin! Electric Paint is not waterproof, but depending on what your application is you can paint over it with a waterproof paint or varnish. On the bright side this does make for easy cleanup.

Note: Due to the requirements of shipping the batteries in this kit, orders may take longer to process and therefore do not qualify for same-day shipping. Sorry for any inconvenience this may cause.

Includes:

  • 1x Instruction Booklet
  • 10x Electric Paint Pens
  • 30x Robot Greeting Cards
  • 30x 3V CR1220/1HF Coin Cell Batteries
  • 10x Red LEDs
  • 10x Green LEDs
  • 10x Yellow LEDs

    • Features:

    Water-based, nontoxic and dries at room temperature.

    Electric Paint can be applied to a wide variety of materials, including (but certainly not limited to) paper, cardboard vellum, wood, metal, plaster, some rubbers, plastics and many textile.

    Soap and warm water will take Electric Paint off of most surfaces.

    Can last years if treated properly and kept dry.

    Documents:

    Assembly Instructions

    Datasheet (Electric Paint)

    Datasheet (CR1220)

    Electric Paint MSDS

    Resistance Chart

    Flashing Card Tutorial

    Product Video

    [/ectext]
short_description: Teach students how to build circuits and electronics by drawing them on paper to make electronic greeting cards.

title: Bare Conductive - Electric Paint (50ml)
description:
[ectext]

Bare Conductive’s Electric Paint is just like any other water-based paint… except that it’s electrically conductive! This means that you can actually paint wires onto things like models, clothes, furniture, walls, almost anything you can think of. Standard acrylic or water-based paints can even be used alongside Electric Paint to act as insulation or to create multi-layer circuitry!

You can apply Bare’s Electric Paint like any other water-based paint. You can use a brush, a roller, printmaking equipment, some intrepid users have even tried to spray the material through an airbrush! It’s important to note that as Electric Paint dries the conductivity increases (and will continue to increase to a certain extent even after the paint “feels” dry), so if your project requires calibration, let the paint dry completely before testing it.

Note: Electric Paint is not meant for use on skin!

Note: Electric Paint is not waterproof, but depending on what your application is you can paint over it with a waterproof paint or varnish. On the bright side this does make for easy cleanup.

Features:

  • Water-based, nontoxic and dries at room temperature.
  • Elecric Paint can be applied to a wide variety of materials, including (but certainly not limited to) paper, cardboard vellum, wood, metal, plaster, some rubbers, plastics and many textile.
  • Soap and warm water will take Electric Paint off of most surfaces.
  • Can last years if treated properly and kept dry.
    • [/ectext]
short_description: Paint circuits onto paper with this conductive paint.

title: Lilly Pad Arduino 328 Main Board
description:
[ectext]

This is LilyPad Arduino - the main board consisting of an ATmega328 with the Arduino bootloader and a minimum number of external components to keep it as small (and as simple) as possible. Board will run from 2V to 5V. The latest version of the LilyPad supports automatic reset for even easier programming. The back side of the LilyPad is now completely flat! We now use a surface mount programming connector to keep the header from poking through.

This version of the LilyPad now uses the new ATmega328 at 8MHz. Arduino 0016 supports the Arduino Pro Mini 328/8MHz. Use this setting when using this new LilyPad 328.

LilyPad is a wearable e-textile technology developed by Leah Buechley and cooperatively designed by Leah and SparkFun. Each LilyPad was creatively designed to have large connecting pads to allow them to be sewn into clothing. Various input, output, power, and sensor boards are available. They’re even washable!

Note: A portion of this sale is given back to Dr. Leah Buechley for continued development and education of e-textiles and also to Arduino LLC to help fund continued development of new tools and new IDE features.

Dimensions:

50mm outer diameter

Thin 0.8mm PCB

[/ectext]
short_description: Need to program wearale electronics? Use this microcontroller to "hack your wardrobe."

title: Light Blue Bean - For the Classroom
description: This is an Arduino that is programmable from your iPad. We have soldered female headers onto the I/O pins to make it easy to connect jumper wires. If you order multiple Beans, we will assign them unique names to minimize classroom confusion.The Light-Blue Bean includes an RGB LED, a 3-axis accelerometer, and a temperature sensor. We have used this successfully with novice middle school students up through the most tech-savvy highschooler.
short_description: Hands-down, this is the best Arduino for introducing novice inventors to physical computing and microcontrollers. It is programmable from an iPad or a laptop. Students can code in the block-based language, Tickle, and move up to native Arduino code when they are ready.

title: Make it React! Arduino Kit
description: Younger students will explore basic concepts of circuits and programming fundamentals. Older students will explore resistance, current, and voltage. All students will apply design thinking principles to invent amazing things that respond to the world around them.Our one-of-a-kind method of introducing microcontroller programming enables even novice students to design and build sophisticated electronic inventions. The hardware in this kit is hand-selected to minimize student frustration and increase self-sufficiency. Programming concepts are introduced through a block-based, graphical language. Later, students who are ready can move on to native Arduino code. Programming can be done from an iPad, laptop, or Chromebook.
specifications:
[ectext]

Designed to introduce students to various types of sensors and digital logic, this kit includes the following:

  • Breadboard
  • Battery Pack
  • Arduino
  • Alligator Clips w. Jumper Connectors
  • 10K Ohm Resistor w. Jumper Connector
  • Servo Motor
  • Button
  • Tilt Switch
  • Pressure Sensor
  • Reed Switch
  • Trimmer Pot
  • Flex Sensitive Resistor
  • Photo Resistor
    • [/ectext]
seo_description: Best way to introduce simple arduino sensors to students
seo_keywords: arduino sensors,arduino photocell,arduino photoresistor,arduino sensor kit,simple arduino sensors,sensors for students,arduino for classroom,physical computing
short_description: Invent a laser trip wire that integrates into an iPad game that you design. Build a game controller glove that responds to the bending of your finger. Use your imagination to invent anything that responds to light, temperature, pressure, and motion. Your students will learn some electronics fundamentals as they connect a variety of sensors to an Arduino.

title: Reed Switch
description: This is a small device called a reed switch. When the device is exposed to a magnetic field, the two ferrous materials inside the switch pull together and the switch closes. When the magnetic field is removed, the reeds separate and the switch opens. This makes for a great non-contact switch. This switch can carry up to 1A.This reed switch can be populated easily on a PCB and is encapsulated so it’s more durable than glass reed switches.
short_description: This sensor reacts to a magnetic field. Connect it to an arduino to create a presence or proximity "touchless" sensor.

title: Hall Effect Sensor
description: The US1881 is an integrated Hall effect latched sensor. That’s nice but what does it do? Holding a magnet near the sensor will cause the output pin to toggle. This makes for a robust presence sensor. A reed sensor also works nicely, but can be limited by the glass encapsulation and size. A hall effect sensor is much smaller, but can handle less current than a reed switch.The device includes an on-chip Hall voltage generator for magnetic sensing, a comparator that amplifies the Hall voltage, and a Schmitt trigger to provide switching hysteresis for noise rejection, and open-collector output. An internal bandgap regulator is used to provide temperature compensated supply voltage for internal circuits and allows a wide operating supply range.If a magnetic flux density larger than threshold Bop, DO is turned on (low). The output state is held until a magnetic flux density reversal falls below Brp causing DO to be turned off (high).
short_description: This sensor is triggered when it detects a magnetic field. Use it to build a touchless switch connected to an Arduino.

title: Sphero Sprk Robot
description: There’s no rule that says learning shouldn't be fun, or that playing can’t be valuable. If there is, we created SPRK Edition to break it. We know that kids love Sphero, so we turned that love into learning and creation. SPRK makes the skills of the future approachable and practical. And most importantly, fun.The SPRK app experience lets you give your robot the orders with visual blocks representing code - our own C-based language called OVAL. Immediately see the connection between the program you created and how the guts of your Sphero work and react. Sphero SPRK Edition will inspire a love of robotics, coding, and STEM principles… all through play.SPRK is simple enough for beginners of all ages, yet sophisticated enough for seasoned programmers. The SPRK community is thriving as thousands of kids shape their future through fun and discovery. Fire up your imagination and break the rules about learning.
short_description: This simple, spheriical robot is capable of amazingly complex things. Give kids the tools they need to practice algorithmic thinking and work on exercizes in geometry and physical science. Program it fom your iPad or phone!

title: Sphero Chariot
description: Use this Sphero Accessory to add functionality to Sphero. Make Sphero carry passengers, pull objects, or drag a magic marker.
short_description: Use this Sphero Accessory to add functionality to Sphero. Make Sphero carry passengers, pull objects, or drag a magic marker.

title: Sphero Nubby Cover
description: The product description text should go here...
short_description: Give Sphero some extra traction and protect it from damage with a nubby cover. Available in three vibrant colors.

title: Sphero Turbo Cover
description: This cover protects and gives Sphero traction. It is designed to maximize speed and comes in three speedy colors.
short_description: This cover protects and gives Sphero traction. It is designed to maximize speed and comes in three speedy colors.

title: World Map Robot Activity Mat
description: This vinyl mat makes a great surface for robot challenges.It measures 3' x 6' and has a map of the world printed on it with a centimeter grid over that. Use the grid to learn how to guide the Sphero robot precisely. Use the world map to design various challenges for your students. Map can be written on with washable markers.
short_description: This vinyl mat makes a great surface for robot challenges.It measures 3' x 6' and has a map of the world printed on it with a centimeter grid over that. Use the grid to learn how to guide the Sphero robot precisely. Use the world map to design various challenges for your students. Map can be written on with washable markers.

title: Light Blue Bean
description: Introduce students to Arduino Programming with this Bluetooth enabld microcontroller. IT CAN BE PROGRAMMED FROM AN IPAD. Compaitble with the block-based programming language, Tickle, this is simple enough for beginners and flexible enough for pros. Want to introduce your students to sensors? Thsi has an on-board accelerometer and an on-board temperature sensor.
short_description: Introduce students to Arduino Programming with this Bluetooth enabld microcontroller. IT CAN BE PROGRAMMED FROM AN IPAD. Compaitble with the block-based programming language, Tickle, this is simple enough for beginners and flexible enough for pros. Want to introduce your students to sensors? Thsi has an on-board accelerometer and an on-board temperature sensor.

title: Sphero Dance Party
description: The Sphero robot is going to the Middle School Dance, but he is nervous because he doesn't know any dance moves. Teams of sixth grade students will collaborate to choreograph a dance on grid paper, which they will scale to fit on Sphero's dance floor mat. They will then use algebra to create a program based on sphero's speed and the time it should take to complete each move in the dance. Finally, they will program this dance using the block based programming language, Tickle.
specifications: 5 Sphero Robots5 4'x4' Robot Activity MatsTeacher Guide including daily lesson plans, and links to presentation templates and videos.
short_description: Students will employ math skills such as ratio, scale, and algebraic thinking as they "teach" a shy robot how to dance. This classroom set has enough Robots and equipment for 5 groups of students.

title: Rube Goldberg--Classroom Set
description: Using what they have learned about simple machines, student will design and build a Rube Goldberg invention that utilizes several of the simple machines studied in fifth grade science. They will also incorporate a digital component into the machine using Makey Makey.
specifications: Kit contains:5 Makey Makey Boards1 Teacher's Guide with Detailed LessonsNote that building materials for the Rube Goldberg machine are not supplied in this kit. Students are expected to use a variety of found and recycled material: cardboard, etc..
short_description: In this project, students add a 21st Century flare to a Rube Goldberg invention by incorporating a Makey Makey invention into the machine and programming it to react to a trigger.

title: Squishy Circuits - Tchr Guide
description: Even very young students can learn fundamentals of electricity such as what a circuit is, what is the difference between conductive and insulating. This activity can get them to think about questions such as what ingredient makes the conductive dough different from the insulating dough? Our project based approach gives kids just enough structure to begin truly inventing and creating amazing projects.
short_description: This project gives early childhood students a fun introduction to electircal circuits. Includes instructions for making the dough!

title: Make It All - Tchr Guide
description: Teacher's Guide helps you deliver three basic projects exploring fundamental Arduino and programming skills -- controlling LEDs, Servo Motors, and DC motors. Students also learn programming basics of loop, conditional, variable. This guide includes links to online presentation templates for lessons.
short_description: This is the Teacher's Guide for the Make it All kit. This kit is the best way we know of to teach students the funamentals of Arduino programming and physical computing.

title: Make it All - Sdnt Guide
description: Through fun, engaging projects, students master the fundamentals of Arduino programming such as controlling LEDs, Servos, and DC Motors.
short_description: This is the student guide for the Make it All project kit. This kit is the best method we have found for introducing students to Arduino programming. Student guide includes detailed instructions, illustrations, and worksheets.

title: SparkFun PicoBoard
description: The PicoBoard allows you to create interactions with various sensors. Using the Scratch programming language, you can easily create simple interactive programs based on the input from sensors. The PicoBoard incorporates a light sensor, sound sensor, a button and a slider, as well as 4 additional inputs that can sense electrical resistance via included cables.Note: The PicoBoard is a derivative work of the Scratch Sensor Board.
specifications: Includes:1x PicoBoard4x Tall Silicone Bumpers4x 2.5mm Audio Cable to Dual Alligator Clip
short_description: Designed for educators and beginners, the PicoBoard is a good way to get into the very basics of programming and reading sensors.

title: Sphero Dance Party Teacher Guide
description: Your students will  use ratios, proportions, algebra and coding skills to "teach" a shy robot some dance moves as he gets ready for the big middle school dance. This teachers guide includes links to mini-lesson templates and demonstration videos.
short_description: This teacher guide contains a complete list of activities and lessons to deliver the Sphero Dance Party activity.
